item.title: China Fines GlaxoSmithKline Nearly $500 Million in Bribery Case
item.description: The financial penalty is the largest ever imposed by Beijing, and the British drug maker’s former chief in the country was given a suspended prison sentence.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Patrick Chappatte: Scotland Says No to Independence
item.description: The Scottish referendum returned a majority for staying in the United Kingdom.

item.title: China Fines GlaxoSmithKline Nearly $500 Million in Bribery Case
item.description: Along with the financial penalty, the largest ever imposed by Beijing, the drug maker’s former chief in the country, a Briton, was given a suspended prison sentence.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Scotland Rejects Independence From Britain in Historic Vote
item.description: By a wide margin, Scotland chose not to become an independent country. The leader of the campaign for secession conceded defeat.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Fans Celebrate Li Na’s Historic Career
item.description: On Chinese social media, news of Li Na’s retirement surpassed the initial public offering of Alibaba and the independence referendum in Scotland.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Li Na, the first player from Asia to win a Grand Slam singles title, at the Australian Open in January, when she won her second Grand Slam tournament.

item.title: High Turnout in Tight Vote as the Result Is Awaited
item.description: The ballot count has been careful and slow, with early word suggesting that the movement for Scotland to remain part of Britain was ahead.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: People waited to cast their voted on Thursday in Edinburgh.

item.title: Scotland Rejects Independence From United Kingdom
item.description: The outcome headed off the political, economic and military imponderables that would have accompanied a divorce from the United Kingdom.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Ryan Randall fired up the bagpipes outside an Edinburgh polling place.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Xiao Zhen on Trying to End ‘Gay Conversion Therapy’ in China
item.description: China decriminalized homosexuality in 1997 and declassified it as a mental illness in 2001, but clinics promising to “convert” gay people abound in a country where pressure to join the heterosexual mainstream is high.
item.dc:creator: By BECKY DAVIS

item.title: The TV Watch: The Muddled Message in ISIS’ Latest Agitprop Video
item.description: British journalist John Cantlie appears with a promise to expose Western media, but viewers must be skeptical of every word he speaks under presumed duress.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

item.title: Congress’s Inaction Could Be Legal Basis for Stronger Executive War Powers
item.description: As lawmakers grapple with President Obama’s claim that he already has congressional authorization for airstrikes against the Islamic State, legal specialists are saying that even legislative inaction could create a precedent leaving the executive branch with greater war-making powers.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: World Briefing: Mali: Bomb Kills 5 U.N. Peacekeepers
item.description: A roadside bomb in northern Mali killed five United Nations peacekeepers and wounded several others, a United Nations spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Police and Military Routinely Use Torture, Amnesty International Says
item.description: Most of those detained are denied visits from family or lawyers, said the human rights group in a report compiled from hundreds of testimonies and evidence gathered over 10 years.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Listening Post: A White House Position That Stands on a Narrow Definition of War
item.description: Far from clarifying the war plan, the White House’s public-relations blitz has muddied several key issues, not least whether the campaign will require American ground forces.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Scottish Vote Weighs Pride Against Risk
item.description: While Scots have been warned repeatedly about the dire consequences of voting for independence from the United Kingdom, half — more or less — are expected to do so anyway.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: People waited to cast their voted on Thursday in Edinburgh.

item.title: U.S. Faces Tough Struggle on Ground to Oust ISIS
item.description: The next phase of the American strategy against the Islamic State has been described as “extraordinarily complex,” and involves training and coordinating airstrikes with Iraqi forces.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, ERIC SCHMITT and HELENE COOPER

item.title: U.S. Goal Is to Make Syrian Rebels Viable
item.description: Intelligence agents are laying the groundwork for what they hope will become an effective fighting force of Syrian rebels that will serve as ground troops in the battle against the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rebel leader, Sheikh Tawfiq Shahabuddin, right, on Monday in Reyhanli, Turkey. “The international position has to be to fight all kinds of terrorism,” he said.

item.title: World Briefing: Chile: 3 Suspects Arrested in Bombing
item.description: Chilean officials said Thursday that they had arrested three members of an anarchist cell suspected in the country’s worst bomb attack in more than two decades.
item.category: Conspiracy of the Cells of Fire
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Syria: Opposition Investigates Vaccine
item.description: Officials of the Syrian opposition coalition said they had created a commission of inquiry into the deaths of children caused by adulterated measles vaccine administered this week.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Deadly Attacks Strike Baghdad
item.description: At least 29 people were killed and more than 65 wounded in attacks in and around the predominantly Shiite neighborhood of Kadhimiya in Baghdad.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: New ISIS Video Features British Hostage, John Cantlie, as Spokesman
item.description: The Islamic State released a new message with a British hostage, the journalist John Cantlie, warning the West against another war.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Congress Gives Final Approval to Aid Rebels in Fight With ISIS
item.description: Lawmakers sidestepped the debate over the extent of American military action until the lame-duck session of Congress later this year.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN WEISMAN and JEREMY W. PETERS

item.title: Fear of Ebola Drives Mob to Kill Officials in Guinea
item.description: Eight people were killed near a remote village in Guinea after a rock-hurling mob attacked them, claiming they had come to spread the Ebola virus.
item.dc:creator: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI

item.title: In Closing Arguments, Arab Bank’s Role in Flagging Terrorists Is Debated
item.description: The federal civil trial, in Brooklyn, pits the bank against victims of terrorist attacks in and around Israel that they say were carried out by Hamas.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHANIE CLIFFORD

item.title: As Moscow’s Landfills Near Limits, Recyclers Do Whatever It Takes
item.description: A small but growing movement is working to make it easier to recycle household waste, and advocates say Moscow’s brimming landfills could use the relief.
item.dc:creator: By SALLY McGRANE
item.media:credit: Denis Sinyakov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elena Barysheva, founder of Recyclemag.ru, carried her recyclables on the Moscow Metro last week.

item.title: Ebola Presents Challenge, and an Opportunity, for U.N. Leader
item.description: For Ban Ki-moon, in his seventh year leading the United Nations, Ebola represents a crucial test — but also an opportunity to lead the global response in fighting the outbreak.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, and Samantha Power, the American envoy, at a Council session Thursday.
